Al(PO3)3 supported NiMo bimetallic catalyst for selective synthesis of fatty alcohols from lipids Long Chen Investigation Data curation Writing – original draft Conceptualization Methodology Supervision Writing – review & editing a Jing Wu Investigation Data curation Writing – original draft Conceptualization Methodology Supervision Writing – review & editing b Guo-Ping Lu Conceptualization Methodology Supervision Writing – review & editing a ⁎ Qiang Zhang Investigation Data curation Writing – original draft c Tianyue Su Investigation Data curation Writing – original draft a Chun Cai Investigation Data curation Writing – original draft Conceptualization Methodology Supervision Writing – review & editing a ⁎ a School of Chemistry and Chemical Engineering, Nanjing University of Science and Technology, Nanjing 210094, China School of Chemistry and Chemical Engineering, Nanjing University of Science and Technology Nanjing 210094 China aSchool of Chemistry and Chemical Engineering, Nanjing University of Science and Technology, Nanjing 210094, China b China Coal Technology Engineering Group Huaibei Blasting Technology Research Institute Limited Company, Huaibei 235000, China China Coal Technology Engineering Group Huaibei Blasting Technology Research Institute Limited Company Huaibei 235000 China bChina Coal Technology Engineering Group Huaibei Blasting Technology Research Institute Limited Company, Huaibei 235000, China c School of Chemistry and Life Sciences, Suzhou University of Science and Technology, Suzhou 215009, China School of Chemistry and Life Sciences, Suzhou University of Science and Technology Suzhou 215009 China cSchool of Chemistry and Life Sciences, Suzhou University of Science and Technology, Suzhou 215009, China ⁎ Corresponding authors. An efficient Al(PO3)3-supported NiMo bimetallic catalyst for the hydrodeoxygenation of lipids to alcohols has been developed. A Ni-Mo synergistic catalytic effect is found, in which H2 is mainly activated by Ni0 and Ni3P sites, and lipids are mainly absorbed on Mo sites. Al(PO3)3 can not only inhibit the oxidation of Ni and Mo species, and but also promote the formation of Ni3P, both of which is favorable to the reaction. Furthermore, this material also displays excellent stability and reusability. Graphic abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords Bimetallic catalysis Aluminum metaphosphate Fatty alcohol Lipid Hydrodeoxygenation Data Availability No data was used for the research described in the article. 1 Introduction Fatty alcohols as significant chemicals are widely applied in lubricants, food additives, surfactants, plasticizers, cosmetics and pharmaceuticals [1–3], which are generally produced from petrochemical raw materials or biomass (such as vegetable oils and animal fats). In the view of the green chemistry, the hydrodeoxygenations (HDO) of lipids (vegetable oils, animal fats, fatty acids and their esters) are better choice for the synthesis of fatty alcohols. Therefore, a large number of efficient catalytic systems have been developed for this transformations [4–5]. There are two main strategies for HDO of lipid to alcohols: Catalytic hydrogenation [6–7] and catalytic transfer hydrogenation [8–10]. Although the conditions of catalytic transfer hydrogenation may be milder and safer, catalytic hydrogenation has better atom economy and lower cost, thereby more suitable for large-scale production. In order to solve the issues of catalyst recovery and product separation [11–18], lots of transition-metal based heterogeneous catalysts have been disclosed for the HDO of fatty acids to alcohols [6–10]. Noble metal-based (Ru, Pt, Re, Pd) heterogeneous catalysts are preferred catalysts for the HDO of lipids to fatty alcohols owing to their excellent ability to activate hydrogen [7,11–18]. For example, Zhao's group has found that Ru3Sn7 nanoclusters on SiO2 were responsible for the selective hydrogenation of diverse fatty acids and coconut oil to fatty alcohols (240 °C, 4 MPa H2) [15]. Hardacre has developed a Pt/TiO2 catalyst to realize the HDO of carboxylic acid to alcohol with 82% conversion and 93% selectivity at mild reaction conditions (130 °C and 2 MPa H2) [16]. In the view of sustainability, non-noble metal-based heterogeneous catalysts maybe a better choice, but the poor catalytic performance of these materials limits their applications. For example, commercial Cu-Cr catalysts require harsh conditions (200∼400 °C, 20∼30 MPa of H2) [19–20]. Various efficient non-noble metal-based heterogeneous catalysts have also been developed for this process to further optimize the reaction conditions. There are two main strategies for the design of heterogeneous catalysts: (1) Active abundant transition metals (Ni, Co, Cu) are applied for hydrogen activation while acidic supports (TiO2, Al2O3, ZrO2, CeO2) are utilized for the adsorption of lipids [21–22]. Co/HAP exhibits the excellent activity for selectively hydrogenating fatty acids and natural oil into fatty alcohols [22], which can be attributed to its acidity, more uniform cobalt particle dispersion, and stronger metal–support interaction. (2) The other is the bimetallic strategy, in which one metal is used to activate H2 and the other metal has a strong adsorption capacity for oxygen species [23–24]. MoOx modified Ni/CeO2 catalyst exhibits the excellent catalytic performance in the conversion of fatty acids to corresponding alcohols [23]. The introduction of Mo species provides much oxygen vacancy sites for the adsorption of fatty acids, Alone this line, we intend to utilize both strategies to explore efficient non-noble metal-based heterogeneous catalysts for this transformation. As is well known, Ni exhibits strong H2 activation ability [25–29], and Mo has strong oxygen affinity [30–32]. Meanwhile, Al(PO3)3 not only contains large number of Lewis acid sites, but also activates the C(sp2)-O bonds of lipids through the potential formation of phenyl phosphate species [33]. Herein, we develop a novel Al(PO3)3-supported NiMo bimetallic catalyst for the HDO of lipids, in which H2 is mainly activated by Ni0 and Ni3P sites, and lipids are mainly absorbed on Mo sites. Al(PO3)3 can not only inhibit the oxidation of Ni and Mo species, and but also promote the formation of Ni3P, both of which is favorable to the reaction. 2 Experimental 2.1 Typical procedures for the synthesis of NixMoy/Al(PO3)3 (x and y mean Ni and Mo mass fraction in the catalyst, respectively) 3.44 g Ni(NO3)2·6H2O, 153.3 mg (NH4)6Mo7O24·4H2O and 15 mL deionized water were mixed and stirred for at least 20 min. Then 2.0 g Al(PO3)3 was added into the solution and stirred for 24 h at room temperature, and then solvent was slowly evaporated. The obtained solid was calcinated at 600 °C for 2 h, then reduced at 500 °C under H2 atmosphere for 2 h to afford Ni25Mo3/Al(PO3)3. The preparation procedures of Ni28/Al(PO3)3, Ni25Mo6/Al(PO3)3 and Ni25Mo9/Al(PO3)3 are the same with Ni25Mo3/Al(PO3)3, but the addition ratio of Ni and Mo salts is different. The preparation procedures of Ni25Mo3/AlPO4, Ni25Mo3/CeO2, Ni25Mo3/Al2O3, Ni25Mo3/ZrO2, are the same with Ni25Mo3/Al(PO3)3, but the use of supports is different. 2.3 Tpyical procedures for the hydrodeoxygenation of lipids to alcohols The catalytic performance tests for the hydrodeoxygenation of lipids to alcohols were carried out in a 50 mL autoclave reactor at a stirring speed of 1000 rpm. Typically, active catalyst (0.1 g), lipid (1 mmol), and n-heptane (9 mL) were added into the autoclave reactor. Then, the autoclave was sealed by bolts, and purged with H2 three times to remove air by a gas pipeline with H2 Cylinder, and pressurized to 2.0 MPa H2. The reaction was performed at 220 °C for 5 h. After the reaction completed, the reaction mixture was cooled and collected. The catalyst was separated by centrifugation, washed by n-heptane. Then, the recycled catalyst was reused for another reaction cycle directly. The liquid phase was analyzed by GC and GC–MS to determine the reaction conversion and selectivity. 3 Results and discussion Initially, the metal loading of all these catalysts were detected by ICP-OES (Table S1). The metal loading is proportional to the amount of metal added during the preparation, but will be slightly lower than the amount of metal added. In the cases of the same amount of metal added, the difference in the metal loadings is not obvious. BET surface area of the Ni25Mo3/Al(PO3)3 is 11.5 m2/g, and its pore volume is 0.029 cm3/g (Table S2), so there is no obvious porous structure in this catalyst. As shown in Fig. 1 , the signals of Ni(0) and Ni3P in the catalyst gradually weakened with the increase of Mo content, while the signals of AlPO4 is inversely proportional to Mo content. There is only a very weak Ni3P signal in the case of Ni25Mo9/Al(PO3)3. No Ni(0) single is found in both cases of Ni25Mo6/Al(PO3)3 and Ni25Mo9/Al(PO3)3, but obvious Ni2P2O7 and NiO peaks are observed. During liquid phase mixing, Al(PO3)3 slowly hydrolyzes to phosphoric acid and aluminum phosphate, which is a chemical equilibrium (Fig. 1 b, Eq. 1). Then, (NH4)2MoO4 can react with phosphoric acid and Ni(NO3)2 to form nickel phosphomolybdate (Ni3P2(Mo3O10)8), resulting in further hydrolysis of Al(PO3)3 to phosphoric acid (Fig. 1 b, eq. 2). Ni3P2(Mo3O10)8 cannot be reduced to Ni0 at 400 °C under hydrogen atmosphere [34], but NiO and Ni3P2(Mo3O10)8 is obtained instead. To probe the electronic states of obtained catalysts, they were detected by X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) (Fig. 2 ). With the increase of Mo content, the signal of Ni0 in the catalyst gradually weakens, which is consistent with the XRD results (Fig. 2 a). In comparison of Ni25Mo3/Al2O3, Ni and Mo species in Ni25Mo3/Al(PO3)3 have lower oxidation states (stronger Ni0 and Mo4+ signals) (Fig. 2 a, b) owing to smaller specific surface area and reducibility of Al(PO3)3. The single of P2− and P − is inversely proportional to the Mo content, further verifying that the introduction of Mo inhibits the Ni3P species (Fig. 2 c). According to TEM results (Fig. 3 ), Ni elements are mainly distributed on the surface of the carrier (Al(PO3)3) in the form of nanoparticles (Fig. 3 d). Mo is relatively uniformly distributed on the surface of Al(PO3)3, and no obvious MoOx particles are found, which is consistent with XRD results (Fig. 3 e). With these NiMo bimetallic catalysts in hands, the HDO of stearic acid to stearyl alcohol was selected as the model reaction to test their catalytic performance (Table 1). The Ni content is proportional to the reaction yield (entries 1–4), since Ni is the main active site for this reaction [35–37]. The addition of a small amount of Mo greatly enhance the activity of the catalyst (entries 3 vs 5), while the HDO reaction is inhibited as the Mo content continues to increase (entries 6–8). Mo has excellent adsorption capacity for oxygen species [30–32], so doping a small amount of Mo in the catalyst can improve the adsorption and activation capacity of reactants and intermediates, which is beneficial to the reaction. According to XRD and XPS results, Ni0 and Ni3P species that are the main catalytic active sites in the catalyst [38–40], decrease with increasing Mo content thereby weakening catalyst activity. After screening different supports, Al(PO3)3 is the best option (entries 9–12). It is found that a 90% yield of octadecanol could be obtained within 5 h after further optimizing the reaction time (entry 13). No reaction took place in the absence of Ni25Mo3/Al(PO3)3 (entry 14), further verifying the effect of the catalyst. Other lipids including palmitic acid, methyl stearate and glyceryl tristearte were also applied in the protocol (Fig. 4 ). Palmitic acid can be converted to corresponding alcohol with 88% yield, but only moderate yields of stearyl alcohol in both cases of methyl stearate and glyceryl tristearte. The kinetic studies suggest that both H2 pressures and concentration of stearic acid are proportional to the initial reaction rate (Fig. 5 a, b), indicating that there is no competition between the adsorption of H2 and stearic acid on the catalyst surface. This result further verifies that Ni (adsorption and activation of H2) and Mo sites (adsorption and activation of O species) play different roles in this reaction. To further illustrate the role of Mo sites in the reaction, both NH3- and CO2-TPD of Ni25Mo3/Al(PO3)3 and Ni28/Al(PO3)3 were performed (Fig. 5 c, d). These results indicate that the introduction of Mo can simultaneously increase the Lewis acid-base sites of the catalyst, which is beneficial to the adsorption and activation of substrates and intermediates in the reaction. Catalyst recycling is an important issue for sustainable development of catalytic process. Thus, the reusability of the catalyst was investigated (Fig. 6 ). This catalyst could be easily recovered via centrifugation separation, and reused for next run after n-heptane washing. After 5 runs, no significant loss of efficiency was observed, indicating that Ni25Mo3/Al(PO3)3 displays excellent stability and reusability. 4 Conclusions In summary, a newly developed Al(PO3)3-supported NiMo bimetallic catalyst (Ni25Mo3/Al(PO3)3) has been disclosed, which exhibits excellent performance (220 °C, 2 MPa, 5 h) on the hydrodeoxygenation of lipids to alcohols owing to the Ni-Mo synergistic catalysis and the nature of Al(PO3)3. According to control experiments, TPD results and kinetic studies, Ni (adsorption and activation of H2) and Mo sites (adsorption and activation of O species) play different roles in this reaction. Al(PO3)3 can not only inhibit the oxidation of Ni and Mo species, and but also promote the formation of Ni3P, both of which is favorable to the reaction. Finally, this catalyst can be recycled at least five times without loss of efficiency. coredata.dc:description: An efficient Al(PO3)3-supported NiMo bimetallic catalyst for the hydrodeoxygenation of lipids to alcohols has been developed. A Ni-Mo synergistic catalytic effect is found, in which H2 is mainly activated by Ni0 and Ni3P sites, and lipids are mainly absorbed on Mo sites. Al(PO3)3 can not only inhibit the oxidation of Ni and Mo species, and but also promote the formation of Ni3P, both of which is favorable to the reaction. Furthermore, this material also displays excellent stability and reusability.
coredata.dc:title: Al(PO3)3 supported NiMo bimetallic catalyst for selective synthesis of fatty alcohols from lipids
